thread.title: From near-death to art: How Flay revived the Paris art scene
thread.title_full: From near-death to art: How Flay revived the Paris art scene

title: From near-death to art: How Flay revived the Paris art scene
text: > Entertainment From near-death to art: How Flay revived the Paris art scene In this photo taken Monday, Oct. 19, 2015 FIAC Director, Jennifer Flay, poses during an interview with The Associated Press in Paris France. Her neck was broken and she was being kept alive by machines after the car crash that nearly killed her. Most people who come back from these make-or-break moments in life find religion, others new meaning to life, but very few decide to take on an “insignificant” Paris art fair on the brink of collapse and succeed in transforming it into one of the most influential in the world. But there’s nothing ordinary about bright-eyed New Zealander Jennifer Flay, 56, who in 2003 defied her instincts to say “no” and took on the challenge to lead France’s Foire International d’Art Contemporain _ and herself _ on an incredible journey. (AP Photo/Jacques Brinon)
